profileText: A Representative from Michigan; born in Greencastle, Franklin County, Pa., August 1, 1807; was graduated from Dickinson College, Carlisle, Pa., in 1829; engaged in teaching; studied law; was admitted to the bar in Chambersburg, Pa., in 1832; moved to Pittsburgh, Pa., and thence, in February 1833 to Monroe, Mich., and engaged in the practice of law; delegate to the convention called to frame a constitution for the proposed State of Michigan in 1835 and to the State constitutional conventions in 1850 and 1867; member of the board of regents of the University of Michigan at Ann Arbor in 1837 and 1850; member of the State house of representatives in 1837, 1839, and 1843, in the latter year being chosen speaker; mayor of Monroe in 1841; elected as a Democrat to the Twenty-eighth, Twenty-ninth, and Thirtieth Congresses (March 4, 1843-March 3, 1849); chairman, Committee on Commerce (Twenty-ninth Congress); was not a candidate for renomination in 1848; delegate to the Democratic National Conventions in 1848, 1852, and 1868; delegate to the Democratic State convention in 1850; Governor of Michigan 1851-1853; resigned to accept appointment as Secretary of the Interior in the Cabinet of President Pierce March 7, 1853, and served until March 6, 1857; resumed the practice of law in Detroit, Mich., where he died August 30, 1880; interment in Elmwood Cemetery.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: McClelland, Robert. Defence [sic] of General Cass. [Washington: Printed at the Congressional Globe Office, 1848].
------. Letter on the crisis, by Hon. Robert McClelland. [Detroit: N.p., 1861].

researchRecord.name: December 26, 1843; April 15, 1854; May 3, 1855. 3 letters.
researchRecord.description: Personal and official correspondence. Finding aid in repository.

researchRecord.name: 1856-1857, 1 volume.
researchRecord.description: This letter press book of Robert McClelland includes 345 items and was kept while he was Secretary of the Interior.

researchRecord.name: 1853-1862, 15 items.
researchRecord.description: The papers of Robert McClelland are a part of the Miscellaneous Manuscripts Collection. Subjects covered in the papers include cabinet officers, governors of Michigan, and Michigan Representatives in the U.S. Congress.

researchRecord.name: 1833-1862. 2 boxes.
researchRecord.description: Correspondence, chiefly with Lewis Cass.

researchRecord.name: In Frederick Rohnert papers, 1725-1896.
researchRecord.description: 1 volume (50 items).

researchRecord.name: 1829-1870, 0.2 linear foot and 1 oversize item.
researchRecord.description: The papers of Robert McClelland include a Latin salutatory for the opening of Dickinson College in 1829, a biographical sketch of Robert McClelland, a letter from Robert McClelland to Augusta McClelland in 1861 affirming his strong loyalty to the Union, two notebooks containing campaign speeches and notes on the Civil War; a diary from 1870 detailing Robert McClelland's travels throughout western Europe, and a notice of appointment to the University of Michigan Board of Regents in 1837.

researchRecord.name: In the Isaac Peckham Christiancy Papers, 1830-1874, 1 linear foot.
researchRecord.description: The papers include business letters from Isaac Christiancy's law partner, Robert M. McClelland. The papers are also available on microfilm. A finding aid is available in the library.
